heading.title: PART 21 DISCOVERY, INSPECTION AND NOTICE TO PRODUCE DOCUMENTS [rr 21.1–21.13]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 21 DISCOVERY, INSPECTION AND NOTICE TO PRODUCE DOCUMENTS [rr 21.1–21.13]
[r 21.5] r 21.5 Documents to be made available (cf SCR Part 23, rule 3(9) and (10); DCR Part 22, rule 3(9) and (10))

leg:heading.title: Documents to be made available (cf SCR Part 23, rule 3(9) and (10); DCR Part 22, rule 3(9) and (10))

p.text: Subject to the requirements of any Act or law, Party B must ensure that the documents described in Part 1 of the list of documents (other than privileged documents):
are physically kept and arranged in a way that makes the documents readily accessible and capable of convenient inspection by party A, and
are identified in a way that enables particular documents to be readily retrieved,
from the time the list of documents is served on party A until the time the trial of the proceedings is completed.
[subr (1) subst Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[6], effective 9 June 2006]
Within 21 days after service of the list of documents, or within such other period or at such other times as the court may specify, party B must, on request by party A:
produce for party A’s inspection the documents described in Part 1 of the list of documents (other than privileged documents), and

make available to party A a person who is able to, and does on party A’s request, explain the way the documents are arranged and assist in locating and identifying particular documents or classes of documents, and
provide facilities for the inspection and copying of such of the documents (other than privileged documents) as are not capable of being photocopied, and
provide photocopies of, or facilities for the photocopying of, such of the documents as are capable of being photocopied, subject to:
party A’s solicitor undertaking to pay the reasonable costs of providing those photocopies or facilities, or
if party A has no solicitor, party A providing to party B an amount not less than a reasonable estimate of the reasonable costs of providing those photocopies or facilities.

The person claiming the benefit of the privilege bears the onus of establishing the factual basis for the claim: Grant v Downs (1976) 135 CLR 674 at 689; 11 ALR 577; BC7600095 ; Re Southland Coal Pty Ltd (rec & mgrs apptd) (in liq) (2006) 59 ACSR 87; [2006] NSWSC 899; BC200606961 (paragraph [14] contains a useful short description of the relevant matters and principles). The rules specifically permit the court to accept evidence to be given in relation to a disputed privilege claim: see UCPR r 1.9(2)(b) . What is relevant, the extent to which the evidence in support of the claim will be accepted as conclusive, and the extent to which competing evidence will be permitted, will vary depending on both the nature of the information for which the privilege is claimed and the particular category of privilege on which the claim is based.

In many instances the privileged character of a particular document may sufficiently appear from its character and description (Grant v Downs (1976) 135 CLR 674 at 689; 11 ALR 577; BC7600095 ) or by inference from the nature and purpose of their legal practitioner’s retainer: Re Southland Coal Pty Ltd (rec & mgrs apptd) (in liq) (2006) 59 ACSR 87; [2006] NSWSC 899; BC200606961 at [28] (supporting evidence provided by solicitor on information and belief). But the question ultimately remains a matter of substance rather than the apparent sufficiency of descriptive verbal formulae: Esso Australia Resources Ltd v Commissioner of Taxation (1999) 201 CLR 49; 168 ALR 123; [1999] HCA 67; BC9908417 at [52] ; Birmingham and Midland Motor Omnibus Co Ltd v London and Northwestern Railway Co [1913] 3 KB 850 at 858 per Hamilton LJ. A person claiming client legal privilege must provide a sufficient factual basis for the claim: Barnes v Cmr of Taxation (2007) 242 ALR 601; (2007) 67 ATR 284; [2007] FCAFC 88; BC200707308 at [16]–[18] ; National Crime Authority v S (1991) 29 FCR 203 at 211; 100 ALR 151 . That may involve specific evidence about the process and purpose underlying the creation of particular documents and the nature and purpose of any related legal advice: Kennedy v Wallace (2004) 142 FCR 185 at 189; 213 ALR 108; [2004] FCAFC 337; BC200409050 (notes prepared for conference with lawyer — claim rejected).

Subject to any particular direction, evidence in support of a claim of privilege, may be given either orally or by affidavit. The court may allow, and the nature of the particular issue may require, not only cross-examination but also conflicting evidence to be given by other parties: National Employers Mutual General Insurance Association Ltd v Waind (1979) 141 CLR 648; 24 ALR 86; BC7900050 ; National Crime Authority v S (1991) 29 FCR 203; 100 ALR 151 . (Although it may be that a claimant party cannot be cross-examined merely on an affidavit verifying discovery: Fruehauf Finance Corp Pty Ltd v Zurich Australian Insurance Ltd (1990) 20 NSWLR 359 ; Brambles Holdings Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1981) 58 FLR 452 .)

For categories of privilege other than client legal privilege, the claim may ultimately depend not so much on disputed questions of primary fact but rather on their application to the appropriate legal criterion. For example, in the case of a disputed claim of Crown privilege, the court (rather than the supporting witnesses) must be satisfied that the interests of administration of justice override the public interest sought to be protected by non-disclosure: Conway v Rimmer [1968] AC 910; [1968] 1 All ER 874 ; Sankey v Whitlam (1978) 142 CLR 1; 21 ALR 505; BC7800068 ; Alister v R (1983-1984) 154 CLR 404. In such cases there is likely to be considerably less scope for competing evidence and cross-examination: Young v Quin (1984) 4 FCR 483 at 484–5; 59 ALR 225.

level.toc-caption: [21.5.75] Privilege — disputed claim — inspection to determine

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.5.75] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.8.

heading.title: Privilege — disputed claim — inspection to determine

p.text: The court has a specific power to inspect documents for the purpose of determining a contested privilege claim: see r 1.8 of the UCPR and the accompanying notes.
Legislation cited in [21.5.80] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 Div 1.

Under Div 1 of Pt 3.10 of the Evidence Act 1995, “client legal privilege” applies to confidential communications and documents where they were made or created for the “dominant purpose” of obtaining legal advice or use in connection with the conduct of proceedings. Until the decision in Esso Australia Resources Ltd v FCT (1999) 201 CLR 49; 168 ALR 123; [1999] HCA 67; BC9908417 , Grant v Downs (1976) 135 CLR 674; 11 ALR 577; BC7600095 was authority for the proposition that, at common law, legal professional privilege was confined to confidential communications and documents brought into existence for the “sole purpose” of being submitted to legal advisers for advice or for use in legal proceedings: see also National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Waind [1978] 1 NSWLR 372 and on appeal National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Waind (1979) 141 CLR 648; 24 ALR 86 . The decision in Esso , above, re-established the “dominant purpose” test at common law. (It should be noted, however, that the statutory criteria will apply to most, if not all, interlocutory issues of discovery, production and inspection: see [1.9.3] and [21.5.55] .)

Burden of proof issues that arise in connection with any privilege claim are discussed in [21.5.70] . Particular examples, that may inform the determination of “dominant purpose”, are provided in [21.5.35] and [21.5.37] .

level.toc-caption: [21.5.85] Self incrimination privilege — Evidence and CPA certificates

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.5.85] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 128, s 128(8), s 128A, s 87(8).
(NSW) Crown Proceedings Act 1988 s 87.

heading.title: Self incrimination privilege — Evidence and CPA certificates

p.text: Under s 128 of the Evidence Act 1995, the court is obliged to offer a certificate of immunity to a witness who has reasonable grounds for objecting to answering questions on the grounds of self-incrimination. A similar certificate procedure applies in relation to interlocutory evidence and to the production of documents in compliance with orders of the court: see Evidence Act s 128A and CPA s 87 . If the witness gives evidence, or produces documents, after properly claiming the privilege, the court is obliged to give a certificate in accordance with the sections. If the court disallows such an objection and thereafter it appears that the claim was justified, a certificate must also be issued. Finally the court has a discretion, exercisable in the “interests of justice”, to direct a witness to answer questions notwithstanding a valid objection based on the privilege against incrimination. If a witness answers pursuant to such a direction the court is also obliged to give a certificate under the section. The certificate grants the witness immunity from any subsequent use of the answers, including immunity against the use of any documents or information obtained as a consequence of the witness having given evidence: see Evidence Act 1995 s 128(8) and CPA s 87(8) . Importantly, the provisions of s 128 apply in circumstances where the evidence in question may tend to prove that the witness has either committed an offence (see Versace v Monte [2001] FCA 1572; BC200107025 or is liable to a civil penalty (see Rich v Australian Securities and Investments Commission (2004) 209 ALR 271; 50 ACSR 242; [2004] HCA 42; BC200405817 . The provisions do not, however, apply in proceedings before the Coroner: Decker v State Coroner (NSW) (1999) 46 NSWLR 415; [1999] NSWSC 369; BC9901835 .
Legislation cited in [21.5.90] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 128, s 87.

The privilege against self-incrimination permits a person to refuse to answer questions or produce documents where there are reasonable grounds to apprehend that compliance would expose the person to a criminal charge, or to proceedings for a civil penalty: Evidence Act 1995 s 128 ; CPA s 87 ; Blunt v Park Lane Hotel Ltd [1942] 2 KB 253 at 257 ; Lamb v Munster (1882) 10 QBD 110 ; R v Slaney (1832) 5 C & P 213; 172 ER 944; Short v Mercier (1851) 3 Mac & G 205; 42 ER 239. The protection that the privilege confers extends not only to the risk of incrimination by direct evidence (that is evidence of the fact of disclosure) but also to incrimination by indirect or derivative evidence (that is evidence obtained by using the disclosed material as a basis of investigation): Rank Film Distributors Ltd v Video Information Centre [1982] AC 380 at 443; [1981] 2 All ER 76 ; Reid v Howard (1995) 184 CLR 1; 131 ALR 609 at 611 . The privilege applies where the risk of incrimination relates to proceedings outside the jurisdiction: Rio Tinto Zinc Corp v Westinghouse Electric Corp [1978] AC 547; [1978] 1 All ER 434 ; or proceedings taken under a foreign law: Rio Tinto Zinc Corp v Westinghouse Electric Corp, above: Evidence Act 1995 Dictionary Pt 2 cl 3; CPA s 87 (definition of “culpable conduct”). The privilege against self-incrimination does not apply to proceedings that are protective rather than punitive, but the limit of its possible application to various different types of civil proceedings is unclear: Redfern v Redfern [1891] P 139 (information with respect to adultery); Law Society v S (NSWSC, Sheppard J, 5 July 1978, unreported) (disciplinary proceedings against a solicitor).

Statutory provisions that compel or authorise the disclosure of information to official bodies are frequently complemented either by prohibitions upon, or immunity from compulsory, further disclosure of the information. But restrictions of these kinds will generally not be construed as preventing, or requiring compliance with, orders for discovery and inspection in legal proceedings, unless the legislation contains a clear contrary indication: Canadian Pacific Tobacco Co Ltd v Stapleton (1952) 86 CLR 1; [1953] ALR 603 (s 16 of the Income Tax and Social Service Contribution Act 1936); Miller v Miller (1978) 141 CLR 269; 22 ALR 119 (Telephonic Communications (Interception) Act 1960); Irvin v Whitrod [1978] Qd R 137 ; Parkes Management Ltd v Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd [1979] 1 NSWLR 274 at 275–7 ; Federal Cmr of Taxation v Nestle Australia Ltd (1986) 12 FCR 257 at 261; 69 ALR 445 ; Sanko Steamship Co Ltd v Sumitomo Australia Ltd (1992) 37 FCR 353 . Difficult problems in the exercise of the discretion to require production arise where compliance with the order would be contrary to secrecy provisions in the legislation of a foreign state: see, for example, Rio Tinto Zinc Corp v Westinghouse Electric Corp [1978] AC 547; [1978] 1 All ER 434 ; see also “Aspects of Conflict of Laws in Banking Transactions” (1987) 61 ALJ 65.

level.toc-caption: [21.5.100] Public interest immunity — Evidence Act 1995 s 130

heading.title: Public interest immunity — Evidence Act 1995 s 130

p.text: Public interest immunity from disclosure does not depend upon the objection of a particular party, but is one that a judge may raise of their own initiative. However, the court is entitled to give weight to the fact that an objection has not been made by the relevant person when the opportunity to do so arose: Sankey v Whitlam (1978) 142 CLR 1; 21 ALR 505; BC7800068 . In determining a claim for public interest immunity the court must balance the particular public interest that is sought to be protected by non disclosure against the public interest in the proper administration of justice: Sankey v Whitlam , above; Commonwealth v Northern Land Council (1991) 30 FCR 1; 103 ALR 267 (no automatic privilege for cabinet documents); see also Gartside v Outram (1856) 26 LJ Ch 113 ; Conway v Rimmer [1968] AC 910; [1968] 1 All ER 874 ; Alfred Crompton Amusement Machines Ltd v Customs and Excise Cmrs (No 2) [1974] AC 405; [1973] 2 All ER 1169 (information obtained confidentially by the Crown for valuing goods for tax purposes); Rogers v Home Secretary [1973] AC 388; [1972] 2 All ER 1057 (confidential inquiries by the Gaming Board from the police as to applicants for certificates of consent, protected); Norwich Pharmacal Co v Customs and Excise Cmrs [1974] AC 133; [1973] 2 All ER 943 (names of persons likely to have violated plaintiff’s patent rights not protected); D v National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children [1978] AC 171; [1977] 1 All ER 589 (information as to ill treatment of children given to a charitable body having statutory authority to bring proceedings protected though the body was not a government instrumentality); Thompson v Inner London Education Authority [1977] LS Gaz R 66; Secretary of State for Trade and Industry v Hoffmann-La Roche & Co AG [1975] AC 295 at 361; [1973] 3 All ER 945 ; Melasecca v R (1994) 74 A Crim R 210; BC9406007 (documents relating to police investigations and identity of informers); Neilson v Laugharne [1981] 1 QB 737 (statements taken in the course of an investigation into police misconduct); Aboriginal Sacred Sites Protection Authority v Maurice (1986) 10 FCR 104; 65 ALR 247 ; Borg v Barnes (1987) 10 NSWLR 734 (communications with Bar Association and Law Society involving complaints against legal practitioners — disclosure ordered); Finch v Grieve (1991) 22 NSWLR 278. In deciding whether or not documents should be produced the ultimate test is whether their production is necessary for the purpose of disposing fairly of the proceedings: Burmah Oil Co Ltd v Bank of England [1980] AC 1090 ; Science Research Council v Nasse [1980] AC 1028; [1979] 3 All ER 673 ; Campbell v Tameside Metropolitan Borough Council [1982] 1 QB 1065; [1982] 2 All ER 791 .

Where the claim of privilege relies upon public interest immunity, no question of waiver can arise: Air Canada v Secretary of State for Trade (No 2) [1983] 2 AC 394 ; Special Minister of State v Quin (1984) 3 FCR 293 ; Australian Securities Commission v Zarro (1992) 34 FCR 427; 10 ACLC 553 .

level.toc-caption: [21.5.107] Public interest immunity — appointment of special counsel

heading.title: Public interest immunity — appointment of special counsel

p.text: It may be appropriate for the court to appoint special counsel to assist in the resolution of contested issues of public interest immunity. The power to do so derives from the overriding purpose provisions of the CPA: New South Wales v Public Transport Ticketing Corp (No 3) [2011] NSWCA 200; BC201105439 (large numbers of documents — reduction of court time — disclosure to special counsel consistent with fairness without public disclosure). Alternatively the Supreme Court may have an inherent power to make such an appointment: New South Wales v Public Transport Ticketing Corp (No 3) [2011] NSWCA 200 ; BC201105439. A mechanism for appointment of special counsel is set out in New South Wales v Public Transport Ticketing Corp (No 3) [2011] NSWCA 200; BC201105439 at [40].
Legislation cited in [21.5.110] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 122(5)(a), s 122(1).

If privilege has been claimed for a document and its production successfully resisted on that ground, the document cannot subsequently be used in the proceedings by the party who claimed the privilege unless the opposing party is first given an opportunity to inspect it. Depending upon the materiality of the document and the circumstances of the litigation, the belated disclosure may justify the grant of an adjournment to the inspecting party: Somerville v Australian Securities Commission (1993) 118 ALR 149; BC9304168 ; Buttes Gas & Oil Co v Hammer (No 3) [1981] QB 223; [1980] 3 All ER 475; [1980] 3 WLR 668 .

Privilege may be waived intentionally or by implication: see further [51,090.10]. Waiver may occur as a result of the actions of the privilege holders or their lawyers. (A lawyer has an implied authority to waive privilege in the course of litigation: B v Auckland District Law Society [2003] 2 AC 736 at 756; [2003] 3 WLR 859 ; Spedley Securities Ltd (in liq) v Bank of New Zealand (1991) 26 NSWLR 711 at 729–30; 6 ACSR 331 ; Griffıth v Evans [1953] 1 WLR 1424 at 1431 , see also Evidence Act 1995 s 122(1) .) In determining whether waiver has occurred it is not necessary that the disclosure relied upon should be the action of the privilege holder in putting the privileged material into evidence and thereby “deploying them in court” in the sense in which that expression was used by Mustill J in Nea Karteria Maritime Co Ltd v Atlantic & Great Lakes Steamship Corp (No 2) [1981] Com LR 138 ; Attorney-General (NT) v Maurice (1986) 161 CLR 475; 69 ALR 31 ; cf United States Surgical Corp v Hospital Products International Pty Ltd (NSWSC, McLelland J, No 2094/81, 13 October 1981, unreported). Conversely, indication of an intention to tender, or otherwise rely on a document at the hearing, does not involve a waiver of privilege in the absence of any disclosure of the contents of the document: Victoria v Davies (2003) 6 VR 245 at 256–8; [2003] VSCA 65; BC200302798 (inclusion of document description in index of court bundle).

Waiver may arise from disclosure made in the course of negotiations: Argyle Brewery Pty Ltd v Darling Harbourside (Sydney) Pty Ltd (1994) 48 FCR 1; 120 ALR 537. Surrender of the documents will normally constitute an express waiver of privilege, unless the disclosure is mistaken, compulsory or confidential.

mistaken disclosure: There is no waiver if disclosure occurs by mistake — as where obviously privileged documents are inadvertently included in discovered documents: Hooker Corp Ltd v Darling Harbour Authority (1987) 9 NSWLR 538 ; Great Atlantic Insurance Co v Home Insurance Co [1981] 2 All ER 485; [1981] 1 WLR 529; [1981] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 138 ; Kabwand Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd (1987) 16 FCR 85; 81 ALR 721 .

confidential or compulsory disclosure: No waiver applies to mutual disclosure between persons jointly entitled to claim privilege in the documents: Mercantile Mutual Insurance (NSW Workers Compensation) Ltd v Murray (2004) 13 ANZ Ins Cas ¶61-612; [2004] NSWCA 151; BC200403612 (report commissioned by solicitors acting for insured on instructions from insurer); Farrow Mortgage Services Pty Ltd (in liq) v Webb (1996) 39 NSWLR 601 at 608 . There is no waiver where the disclosure is made on a limited basis pursuant to a statutory obligation: Optus Communications Pty Ltd v Telstra Corp Ltd (FCA, Lockhart J, G100/93, 27 April 1995, unreported, BC9506137) (disclosure to minister). And even in the absence of a mandatory disclosure obligation, disclosure for only a limited purpose may not involve waiver of the privilege: Goldman v Hesper [1988] 3 All ER 97; [1988] 1 WLR 1238 (limited disclosure for the purpose of taxation of costs); British Coal Corp v Dennis Rye Ltd (No 2) [1988] 3 All ER 816; [1988] 1 WLR 1113 (disclosure for the purpose of criminal prosecution conducted by police); Bourns Inc v Raychem Corp [1999] 3 All ER 154 (disclosure for the purpose of taxation of costs); McCabe v British American Tobacco Australia Services Ltd (No 4) [2002] VSC 172; BC200202384 at [22] (disclosure to resist a strike out application — claim for privilege rejected); B v Auckland District Law Society, above (disclosure to assist professional conduct investigation). There is no waiver if the disclosure is made confidentially: Carnell v Mann (1998) 89 FCR 247; 159 ALR 647; BC9806603 (disclosure by minister to member of parliament); Evidence Act 1995 s 122(5)(a) .

level.toc-caption: [21.5.115] Waiver — by implication from the nature of the issues for determination

heading.title: Waiver — by implication from the nature of the issues for determination

p.text: Waiver may arise by implication from the nature of the issues for determination. No implied waiver arises if the issues concern only the fact, as distinct from the contents, of a communication between solicitor and client: Carden v CE Heath Casualty & General Insurance Ltd (1992) 7 ANZ Ins Cas ¶61-147; Lake Cumbeline Pty Ltd v Effem Foods Pty Ltd (t/as Uncle Ben’s of Australia) (1994) 126 ALR 58; 13 ACLC 55 (disclosure of memoranda of fees did not waive privilege). But if privilege holders raise an issue about the content of communications with their lawyer, there is an implied waiver of the privilege that would otherwise apply and no objection can thereafter be taken on the grounds of legal professional privilege: Barilla v James (1964) 81 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 457 at 475 ; Thomason v Campbelltown Municipal Council (1939) 39 SR (NSW) 347 at 358 ; George Doland Ltd v Blackburn Robson Coates & Co [1972] 3 All ER 959; [1972] 1 WLR 1338 ; Burnell v British Transport Commission [1956] 1 QB 187 ; Moreay Nominees Pty Ltd v McCarthy (1994) 10 WAR 293 (issue about the solicitor ’s authority to settle proceedings); Benecke v National Australia Bank (1993) 35 NSWLR 110 (extent of lawyer’s authority to settle). Differing views have been expressed as to whether allegations of reliance on a tortfeasor ’s conduct (the allegations thus raising for determination the claimant's state of mind) constitute an implied waiver of communications between the plaintiff and its legal advisors: Telstra Corp Ltd v BT Australasia Pty Ltd (1998) 85 FCR 152 at 167; 156 ALR 634 (privilege waived); John Tanner Holdings Pty Ltd v Mortgage Management Ltd (2001) 182 ALR 201; [2001] FCA 194; BC200100692 (privilege not necessarily waived); Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich [2004] NSWSC 1089; BC200407581 (privilege waived in relation to parts of the advice).
Legislation cited in [21.5.120] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 126.

Disclosure of the existence of a document does not constitute waiver of privilege. Thus privilege is not waived by the mere reference to a document in pleadings: Roberts v Oppenheim (1884) 25 Ch D 724; Buttes Gas & Oil Co v Hammer (No 3) [1981] 1 QB 223 at 252, 268; [1980] 3 All ER 475 ; or in an affidavit: Lyell v Kennedy (No 3) (1884) 50 LT 730; 27 Ch D 1 at 24 ; Infields Ltd v P Rosen and Sons [1938] 3 All ER 591 at 597 ; unless, of course, the actual contents of the documents are disclosed: Buttes Gas, above, QB at 252. Waiver may be implied, however, where there is a partial disclosure of privileged material. Where waiver is alleged to have occurred by implication from partial disclosure, difficult questions arise both as to whether the conduct in question constitutes waiver and, if it does, as to its extent. In each case the ultimate question is whether maintenance of the privilege would be unfair having regard to the partial disclosure that has been made: Attorney-General (NT) v Maurice (1986) 161 CLR 475; 69 ALR 31 ; s 126 of the Evidence Act 1995. Partial disclosure of the contents of a document may be misleading and fairness may require that the balance of the document also be produced because “the opposite party and the court must have an opportunity of satisfying themselves that what the party has chosen to release from privilege represents the whole of the material relevant to the issue in question. To allow an individual item to be plucked out of context would be to risk injustice through its real weight or meaning being misunderstood”: Nea Karteria Maritime Co Ltd v Atlantic & Great Lakes Steamship Corp (No 2) [1981] Com LR 138 at 139 approved in Attorney-General (NT) v Maurice , above; Great Atlantic Insurance Co v Home Insurance Co [1981] 2 All ER 485; [1981] 1 WLR 529 . However, in dealing with waiver by partial disclosure a distinction needs to be drawn between, on the one hand, disclosure of part of a document, the entirety of which would otherwise be entitled to privilege, and, on the other, a claim for privilege as to part only of a document. It is accepted that a valid claim for privilege may exist as to part only of a document: Grofam Pty Ltd v ANZ Banking Group Ltd (1993) 43 FCR 408; 116 ALR 535 ; Curlex Manufacturing v Carlingford General Insurance [1987] 2 Qd R 335 . Accordingly, in such a case no question of waiver arises where the disclosure made consists of material that is not a valid subject of a claim for privilege in any event.

Waiver by implication may extend to related documents and communications that deal with the same subject matter: General Accident Fire and Life Assurance Corp v Tanter [1984] 1 All ER 35; [1984] 1 WLR 100 . Whether or not this will be so in any particular case will depend upon considerations of fairness and also the circumstances of the original disclosure: Attorney-General (NT) v Maurice (1986) 161 CLR 475; 69 ALR 31 at 35, 39, 47 ; Mancorp Pty Ltd v Baulderstone Pty Ltd (1991) 57 SASR 87 ; British Coal Corp v Dennis Rye Ltd (No 2) [1988] 3 All ER 816; [1988] 1 WLR 1113 (a case where the disclosure of documents for a limited purpose in connection with criminal proceedings was held not to give rise to a general waiver of privilege); see also s 126 of the Evidence Act 1995. Thus, disclosure of documents that would otherwise have been privileged as confidential communications for the dominant purpose of obtaining legal advice, will not necessarily involve waiver of privilege over related, but later, documents to which litigation privilege may attach: Lowe v Lang [2000] NSWSC 307; BC200001920 .

Documents that have been relied upon by a witness or expert may lose their entitlement to privilege if their disclosure is material to a proper understanding of the evidence given by the witness. However, the mere fact that privileged documents are given to a witness or expert for use in connection with the preparation of their evidence does not necessarily involve any waiver of privilege: Dingwall v Commonwealth (1992) 39 FCR 521 ; Robinson v Adelaide International Raceway Pty Ltd (1993) 61 SASR 279; BC9303956 . Similarly, disclosure of a document does not necessarily involve a waiver of privilege in respect of earlier drafts, particularly in the case of pleadings, affidavits and witness statements: Nilsen Industrial Electronics Pty Ltd v National Semiconductor Corp (1994) 48 FCR 337 at 340; BC9406031 ; Walsham v Stainton (1863) 2 Hem & M 1 at 4; 71 ER 357 at 358; Argyle Brewery Pty Ltd (t/as Craig Brewery Bar & Grill) v Darling Harbourside (Sydney) Pty Ltd (1994) 48 FCR 1; 120 ALR 537. The test as to whether there has been disclosure that waives privilege either in relation to the whole of a document, or in related documents, is whether there has been sufficient disclosure of the effect of the document to warrant loss of privilege: Adelaide Steamships Co Lt v Spalvins (1998) 81 FCR 360; 152 ALR 418 at 425–6; BC9800440 ; BT Australasia Pty Ltd v NSW (1998) 153 ALR 722; BC9801045 .

heading.title: Examples of disclosure of the substance of the evidence — loss of privilege

p.text: Ampolex Ltd v Perpetual Trustee Co (Canberra) Ltd (1995) 37 NSWLR 405; BC9505356 (sentence in Pt B statement the “Ampolex maintains that the correct ratio is 1:1 and has legal advice supporting this position”);

Gazcorp Pty Ltd v Liverpool City Council [2006] NSWSC 490; BC200603705 (“Letter also suggests that Council decision to approve the development for a purpose other than a shop was manifestly unreasonable.”);
NRMA v Morgan (No 2) [1999] NSWSC 694; BC9903815 at [18] (summary form of what counsel had advised);

Thomas v NSW [2006] NSWSC 380; BC200602979 at [17] (service of an affidavit attaching advice of counsel which referred to certain medical reports, waived privilege in the medical reports because they influenced the content of the advice);

AWB Ltd v Cole (No 5) (2006) 155 FCR 50; 234 ALR 651; [2006] FCA 1234; BC200607325 at [168]–[178] (disclosure of the substance of legal advice was inconsistent with the maintenance of confidentiality over such material which underpinned the advice);
Gazcorp Pty Ltd v Liverpool City Council [2006] NSWSC 490; BC200603705 (brief summary of the effect of advice).

heading.title: Examples of insufficient disclosure of the substance of the evidence — no loss of privilege

p.text: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v Australian Safeway Stores Pty Ltd (1998) 81 FCR 526; 153 ALR 393; BC9800786 (reference to a brief without its contents or any summary or extrapolation of the contents is not sufficient);
Southern Cross Airlines Holdings Ltd (in liq) v Arthur Andersen & Co (1998) 84 FCR 472; 28 ACSR 455; BC9803916 (a brief summary of certain advice was insufficient);
NRMA v Morgan (No 2) [1999] NSWSC 694; BC9903815 at [15] (reference to instructing counsel to advise on liability was insufficient).
Legislation cited in [21.5.135] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 131.

Where parties communicate on a “without prejudice” basis in an attempt to negotiate a settlement of a dispute, either party may claim privilege in respect of the contents of their communications. The communications may be privileged even though they relate to the compromise of only some issues in the proceedings: Lukies v Ripley (1994) 35 NSWLR 283 (attempt to agree damages). The privilege extends to communications with third parties: Evidence Act 1995 s 131 . The common law principle that originally established this ground of privilege for “without prejudice” communications, depended partly upon public policy in encouraging the settlement of disputes and partly on implied agreement: Field v Cmr for Railways for New South Wales (1957) 99 CLR 285 at 292; 65 ALR (CN) 1055a ; Walker v Wilsher (1889) 23 QBD 335 at 337 ; Tomlin v Standard Telephones and Cables Ltd [1969] 3 All ER 201; [1969] 1 WLR 1378 at 1383 and 1384 ; Cutts v Head [1984] Ch 290 at 305 ; Rush & Tompkins Ltd v Greater London Council [1988] 1 All ER 549; [1988] 2 WLR 533 . Merely heading correspondence with “without prejudice” will not be sufficient to attract the privilege if the communication is not in fact part of settlement negotiations: Bentley v Nelson [1963] WAR 89 ; Re Daintrey; Ex parte Holt [1893] 2 QB 116 . On the other hand the privilege may apply to bona fide settlement negotiations even though no formal claim of “without prejudice” has been made: Rodgers v Rodgers (1964) 114 CLR 608 at 614; [1965] ALR 109 ; Rush & Tompkins Ltd v Greater London Council [1989] 1 AC 1280; [1988] 3 WLR 939 at 942 ; Lukies v Ripley (1994) 35 NSWLR 283 — unless the correspondence is expressly declared not to be confidential: Evidence Act 1995 s 131(2)(d). Accordingly, if correspondence is headed “without prejudice” the privilege can apply to any subsequent letters in connection with the attempt to negotiate settlement. Even prior letters can fall within the privilege: Field v Cmr for Railways for New South Wales (1957) 99 CLR 285; 65 ALR (CN) 1055a ; Oliver v Nautilus Steam Shipping Co [1903] 2 KB 639 ; GSA Group Pty Ltd v Siebe Plc (1993) 30 NSWLR 573; (1993) ATPR ¶41-240 .

level.toc-caption: [21.5.140] Without prejudice communications — extent of the privilege

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.5.140] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 131(2), s 131(2)(f).

heading.title: Without prejudice communications — extent of the privilege

p.text: The privilege accorded to “without prejudice” communication does not cease on settlement of the proceedings: Rush & Tompkins Ltd v Greater London Council [1989] 1 AC 1280; [1988] 3 WLR 939 ; compare Knapp v Metropolitan Permanent Building Assn (1888) 9 LR (NSW) 468; 5 WN (NSW) 27. But the privilege is not absolute. Documents recording or relating to “without prejudice” negotiations may be admissible in the limited instances provided for in s 131(2) of the Evidence Act 1995. The privilege does not apply to documents used to establish or enforce the settlement: Walker v Wilsher (1889) 23 QBD 335 ; Austotel Management Pty Ltd v Jamieson (1995) 57 FCR 411 ; NSI Group Pty Ltd v Mokas [2006] NSWSC 1077; BC200608171 at [7]–[9] (dispute as to whether agreement to settle was abandoned — correspondence marked “without prejudice” admitted); see also s 131(2)(f) . The privilege does not extend to preclude the proof of communications or statements relied upon to establish an objective act having legal consequences: Wilson v Kingsgate Mining Industries Pty Ltd [1973] 2 NSWLR 713 at 727 ; Lohar Corp Pty Ltd v Dibu Pty Ltd [1976] ACLD 426; (1976) 1 BPR 9177 at 9182 ; Quad Consulting Pty Ltd v David R Bleakley & Assocs Pty Ltd (1990) 27 FCR 86 at 89–93 ; GSA Group Pty Ltd v Siebe Plc (1993) 30 NSWLR 573; (1993) ATPR ¶41-240 ; Re Daintrey; Ex parte Holt , above (documents used to prove an act of bankruptcy); Waldridge v Kennison (1794) 1 Esp 142 (proof of handwriting); Family Housing Assn (Manchester) Ltd v Michael Hyde and Partners [1993] 1 WLR 354 (CA) (without prejudice correspondence is admissible on an application to dismiss for want of prosecution). The privilege does not apply where the disclosure is necessary to negate erroneous inferences that might otherwise arise: McFadden v Snow (1951) 69 WN (NSW) 8 at 10; Pitts v Adney [1961] NSWR 535; (1961) 78 WN (NSW) 836 ; Lohar Corp Pty Ltd v Dibu Pty Ltd , above, at 9182 per Hutley JA.

level.toc-caption: [21.5.145] Without prejudice communications — Calderbank letters and costs

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.5.145] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 131, s 131(2)(h).

heading.title: Without prejudice communications — Calderbank letters and costs

p.text: A communication that is otherwise privileged under s 131 of the Evidence Act 1995 is, nevertheless, admissible on the question of costs: Evidence Act 1995 s 131(2)(h) . The Evidence Act 1995 effectively embraces the decision in Calderbank v Calderbank [1975] 3 All ER 333 at 342; [1976] Fam 93 — where a settlement letter was admitted on the question of costs where it had expressly made the offer subject to a claimed entitlement to use the letter on the question of costs if the offer was not accepted: see also Messiter v Hutchinson (1987) 10 NSWLR 525 ; Computer Machinery Co Ltd v Drescher [1983] 3 All ER 153 at 153; [1983] 1 WLR 1379 . The Evidence Act 1995 will permit the without prejudice offer to be used in relation to costs even where there is no express Calderbank reservation: Bruinsma v Menczer (1995) 40 NSWLR 716 ; contrast Liquorland (Aust) Pty Ltd v GYG Holdings Pty Ltd (NSWCA, Kirby P, Handley and Powell JJA, 27 March 1995, unreported, BC9505008) and Magenta Nominees Pty Ltd v Richard Ellis (WA) Pty Ltd (FCA, Spender, French and Lee JJ, 29 August 1995, unreported, BC9506519). For further discussion of Calderbank letters and costs see [42.13.25] ff.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 21.6] r 21.6 Subsequently found documents to be made available (cf SCR Part 23, rule 3(8); DCR Part 22, rule 3(8))

leg:heading.title: Subsequently found documents to be made available (cf SCR Part 23, rule 3(8); DCR Part 22, rule 3(8))

p.text: If at any time after party B’s affidavit is made, and before the end of the hearing, party B becomes aware:

that any document within the class or classes specified in the relevant order for discovery (not being an excluded document) but not included in Part 1 of the list of documents is within, or has come into, party B’s possession, or
that any document included in Part 1 of the list of documents which was claimed to be a privileged document was not, or has ceased to be, a privileged document,

party B must forthwith give written notice to party A of that fact, and comply with rule 21.5 in respect of the document, as if the document had been included in Part 1 of the list of documents and the list had been served on the date of the giving of the notice.

Under this rule a party is obliged to give continuing discovery of documents that come into its possession, custody or power before the end of the hearing. Furthermore, a party who has given discovery may subsequently become aware, before the end of the proceedings, of further documents that were in fact in its possession, custody or power at the commencement of the proceedings and should have been discovered. In each of those cases, and also if the party becomes aware of the fact that a claim for privilege was not properly made, or of the fact that privilege has been lost, the party must notify the other party of the fact and make the documents in question available for inspection.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 21.7] r 21.7 Discovered documents not to be disclosed (cf SCR Part 23, rule 3(11) and (12); DCR Part 22, rule 3(11) and (12))

leg:heading.title: Discovered documents not to be disclosed (cf SCR Part 23, rule 3(11) and (12); DCR Part 22, rule 3(11) and (12))

p.text: No copy of a document, or information from a document, obtained by party A as a result of discovery by party B is to be disclosed or used otherwise than for the purposes of the conduct of the proceedings, except by leave of the court, unless the document has been received into evidence in open court.
Nothing in subrule (1) affects the power of the court to make an order restricting the disclosure or use of any document, whether or not received into evidence, or the operation of any such order.

level.toc-caption: [21.7.5] Use of discovered documents for collateral purposes

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.7.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 21.7.

heading.title: Use of discovered documents for collateral purposes

p.text: Documents and information obtained on discovery can only be used and disclosed for the purpose of the proceedings, unless either the court grants leave or the material has been received in evidence in the proceedings: UCPR r 21.7 . Originally, discovered documents could be used for any purpose in the absence of any undertaking restricting disclosure. The practice of requiring and obtaining such an undertaking grew up in the middle of the nineteenth century: Richardson v Hastings (1844) 7 Beav 354 at 356 ; Tagg v South Devon Railway Co (1849) 12 Beav 161; 50 ER 1017; Williams v Prince of Wales Life, etc, Co (1857) 23 Beav 338 at 340 ; Reynolds v Godlee (1858) 4 K & J 88 at 91; 70 ER 37; Hopkinson v Lord Burghley (1867) LR 2 Ch App 447. But, it is now clearly established that documents and information that have been compulsorily disclosed to the parties for the purpose of the proceedings are subject to a restriction confining their use and disclosure to the same purpose: Church of Scientology of California v Dept of Health and Social Security [1979] 3 All ER 97; [1979] 1 WLR 723 ; Riddick v Thames Board Mills Ltd [1977] QB 881 at 896; [1977] 3 All ER 677 ; Distillers Co (Biochemicals) Ltd v Times Newspapers Ltd [1975] QB 613 at 621; [1975] 1 All ER 41 at 48 ; Rank Film Distributors Ltd v Video Information Centre [1982] AC 380 at 442; [1981] 2 All ER 76 at 81 ; and see generally Alterskye v Scott [1948] 1 All ER 469 .

Although the restriction is commonly described as an implied undertaking, it is a substantive legal requirement. It operates as a consequence of the compulsory disclosure and irrespective of the affected person’s subjective acknowledgement of its application or the consequences of non-compliance: Hearne v Street (2008) 235 CLR 125; 248 ALR 609; [2008] HCA 36; BC200806976 at [105]–[112] . It operates to prevent the disclosure of documents used in the course of the preparation of criminal proceedings: Taylor v Director of the Serious Fraud Offıce [1999] 2 AC 177; [1998] 4 All ER 801 (contents of documents not able to be disclosed and not actionable) — not following Mahon v Rahn [1998] QB 424; [1997] 3 All ER 687 . It applies also to arbitration proceedings: Esso Australia Resources Ltd v Plowman (1995) 183 CLR 10; 128 ALR 391; BC9506416 .

The general disclosure restriction is not confined to discovered documents. It extends to include any documents and information that has been compulsorily disclosed by other parties (or by other persons in response to subpoenas). It can apply to:

affidavits and witness statements brought into existence for the purpose of particular proceedings: Central Queensland Cement Pty Ltd v Hardy [1989] 2 Qd R 509 (disclosure of witness statements); Springfield Nominees Pty Ltd v Bridgelands Securities Ltd (1992) 38 FCR 217; 110 ALR 685 (disclosure of witness statements); Hearne v Street (2008) 235 CLR 125; 248 ALR 609; [2008] HCA 36; BC200806976 affirming Street v Hearne (2007) 70 NSWLR 231; [2007] NSWCA 113; BC200706638 at [87] (affidavit and expert report);
answers to interrogatories: Ainsworth v Hanrahan (1991) 25 NSWLR 155 ; and

documents produced in response to a court order: Ex parte Coventry Newspapers Ltd [1993] QB 278; [1993] 1 All ER 86 (documents released from implied undertaking despite potential claim for public interest immunity).

Because of its substantive character, and despite its conventional characterisation as an implied undertaking, the disclosure restriction is not limited to the parties to proceedings. It applies to anyone who obtains the documents knowing that they were produced on discovery: Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd v Lovell (1998) 19 WAR 316; BC9802072 (industrial advocate not a party to main proceedings); Harman v Secretary of State for the Home Dept [1983] 1 AC 280; [1982] 1 All ER 532; [1982] 2 WLR 338 (obligation under implied undertaking owed directly by the party’s solicitor — not accessorial or ancillary to that of litigant); Pacific Basin Exploration Pty Ltd v X L X NL [1985] WAR 11; (1984) 2 IPR 489 (managing director of company); Watkins v A J Wright (Electrical) Ltd [1996] 3 All ER 31 (Scottish solicitor who was not an officer of the English court); Street v Hearne , above, (managing director of company and adviser to parent company); Hearne v Street , above, at [103], [109] (directors, officers, employees and agents, potentially including expert witnesses and litigation funders).

The use and disclosure restriction is not confined to instances of bad faith or deliberate impropriety. It extends to any use or disclosure other than for the purpose of the proceedings. Any wider use will be regarded as collateral and consequently improper, unless authorised by prior leave: Harman v Secretary of State for the Home Dept [1983] 1 AC 280; [1982] 2 WLR 338 ; Central Queensland Cement Pty Ltd v Hardy [1989] 2 Qd R 509 ; Ainsworth v Hanrahan (1991) 25 NSWLR 155 at 157, 164, 167, 169 ; Bell Group Ltd (in liq) v Westpac Banking Corp (1998) 86 FCR 215 at 220; 166 ALR 699 (liquidator required leave to use discovered documents and witness statements in the conduct of a examinations under the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth)).

level.toc-caption: [21.7.10] Leave to use for proper purposes

heading.title: Leave to use for proper purposes

p.text: The court may authorise disclosure of documents in a proper case (Initial Services Ltd v Putterill [1968] 1 QB 396; [1967] 3 All ER 145 at 148 ; Beloff v Pressdram [1973] 1 All ER 241 at 260 ; Bray on Discovery, p 239). It may be appropriate, for example, to permit information obtained on discovery in one set of proceedings to be used in a subsequent set of proceedings: Reynolds v Godlee (1858) 4 K & J 88; 70 ER 37; United States Surgical Corp v Hospital Products International Pty Ltd (NSWSC, McLelland J, 7 May 1982, unreported, BC8200010); Crest Homes Plc v Marks [1987] 1 AC 829 (use of documents for the purposes of contempt proceedings in another action). But, to seek disclosure to the media merely for the purpose of satisfying “public interest” will not ordinarily, if ever, be sufficient to warrant relaxation of the general rule: Distillers Co (Biochemicals) Ltd v Times Newspapers Ltd [1975] QB 613; [1975] 1 All ER 41 .
Applications for leave have been granted in the following circumstances:
To use information obtained on discovery in preparing a report required under law in a foreign jurisdiction: Bank of Crete SA v Koskotas (No 2) [1993] 1 All ER 748; [1992] 1 WLR 919 .
To use documents for the purpose of a criminal jurisdiction: Bailey v Australian Broadcasting Corp [1995] 1 Qd R 476 .
Applications for leave have been refused in the following circumstances:

Leave sought to give access to documents covered by undertaking to third parties: British American Tobacco Australia v Cowell (2002) 7 VR 524; [2003] VSCA 43; BC200207341 (US Dept of Justice and ACCC); Dagi v BHP Co Ltd [1996] 2 VR 567; BC9507097 (National Executive Council of Papua New Guinea).
Affidavit of means in matrimonial proceedings not permitted to be used in security for costs application against company controlled by husband: Medway v Doublelock Ltd [1978] 1 All ER 1261 .
Where the document was commercially sensitive and its distribution could prejudice the owner: Bibby Bulk Carriers Ltd v Cansulex Ltd [1989] QB 155; [1988] 2 All ER 820; [1989] 2 WLR 182 .

level.toc-caption: [21.7.15] Disclosure of documents admitted into evidence

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.7.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 21.7.

heading.title: Disclosure of documents admitted into evidence

p.text: Some differences of opinion have been expressed as to whether the substantive restriction on the collateral disclosure of documents and information continues to apply after the information has been received in evidence or referred to in court. If the disclosure merely consists of the documents, or their contents, being referred to in court during the course of the proceedings, the disclosure will not ordinarily operate to release the undertaking: Harman v Secretary of State for the Home Dept [1983] 1 AC 280; [1982] 2 WLR 338 ; Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd v Lovell (1998) 19 WAR 316; BC9802072 . If discovered documents are actually put into evidence “in open court” the UCPR r 21.7 restriction does not apply. This is consistent with the general view that applies to the collateral use of any evidence adduced in proceedings. In such a situation either the disclosure restriction should be regarded as ceasing to apply: Esso Australia Resources Ltd v Plowman (1995) 183 CLR 10 at 32; 128 ALR 391; BC9506416 ; Hearne v Street (2008) 235 CLR 125; 248 ALR 609; [2008] HCA 36; BC200806976 at [96] ; Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd v Lovell , above; contra Harman v Secretary of State for the Home Dept , above; or it should be generally recognised that there is little purpose in requiring the parties to the litigation, or their representatives, to continue to honour any express or implied undertaking preventing their disclosure: United States Surgical Corp v Hospital Products International Pty Ltd (NSWSC, McLelland J, 7 May 1982, unreported, BC8200010). Compare British American Tobacco Australia Services Ltd v Cowell (No 2) (2003) 8 VR 571; [2003] VSCA 43; BC200301919 at [48] (to the extent that knowledge of the document has become public by reason of its tender in open court, members of the public are free to make use of that knowledge as they will, but the party affected by the undertaking remains bound as to the use of the document itself ). However, the view has been expressed that the general restriction against collateral use does continue to apply if the documents and information have only been put into evidence for the purpose of an interlocutory application in the proceedings: British American Tobacco Australia Services Ltd v Cowell (No 2) [2003] VSCA 43; BC200301919 at [50] .

Regulatory authorities may be granted statutory powers to compel the production of documents. The scope of the statutory power will depend, obviously enough, upon the specific terms of the relevant statute. However, if the statutory power is clear, the fact that the documents are held by a party to litigation pursuant to an undertaking, whether express or implied, as to confidentiality, will not constitute a justification for non-compliance with the statutory notice: Australian Securities Commission v Ampolex Ltd (1995) 38 NSWLR 504; 18 ACSR 735 (notice under s 33 of the Australian Securities Commission Law); A v B Bank [1993] QB 311 ; EMI Records Ltd v Spillane [1986] 1 WLR 967 ; Green v FP Special Assets Ltd [1992] 1 Qd R 1 (notice under s 12(3)(c) of the Companies (Queensland) Code).
Legislation cited in [21.7.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 21.7(1).

A subpoena recipient does not require leave to produce documents in compliance with the subpoena, even if the merely voluntary disclosure of the documents would otherwise be conditionally prohibited by r 21.7 applies even if leave of the court were not first obtained: Zhu v Yingle Culture Exchange (Aust) Pty Ltd (in liq) [2009] NSWSC 897; BC200907912 at [12]–[13] (application for order pursuant to r 21.7(1) for leave to produce discovered documents subpoenaed in Federal Court proceedings — leave granted — discussion of whether application for leave was necessary in the circumstances); see also Bell Group Ltd (in liq) v Westpac Banking Corp (1998) 166 ALR 699 at 704; [1998] FCA 849; BC9803285 (“implied obligation must yield to inconsistent statutory provisions and the requirements of the curial process in other litigation eg discovery and inspection”).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 21.8] r 21.8 Personal injury claims (cf SCR Part 23, rule 5; DCR Part 22, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Personal injury claims (cf SCR Part 23, rule 5; DCR Part 22, rule 5)

p.text: In any proceedings on a common law claim:
for damages arising out of the death of, or bodily injury to, any person, or
for contribution in respect of damages so arising,
an order for discovery may not be made in relation to any document unless the court, for special reasons, orders otherwise.

level.toc-caption: [21.8.5] Special reasons — limitation on discovery in personal injury actions

p.text: Legislation cited in [21.8.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 21.12, 22.1(3).

heading.title: Special reasons — limitation on discovery in personal injury actions

p.text: In proceedings for damages arising out of death or personal injury the party seeking discovery bears the onus of establishing special reasons to make an order for discovery. There are similar restrictions in relation to the permissible scope of notices to produce seeking documents (other than those referred to in pleadings, affidavits or witness statements) and in relation to interrogatories: see UCPR rr 21.12 and 22.1(3) .

Despite the impressionistic assessment necessarily involved, a little exegesis is helpful, however, in understanding the way the rule is likely to be applied. The basic requirement for “special reasons” is that the particular circumstances relied on must involve matters different from those ordinarily or commonly encountered: Boscolo v Secretary, Department of Social Security (1999) 90 FCR 531; BC9900369 at [17] ; Cavric v Cooper Lybrand (ACT) Ltd [2002] NSWSC 538; BC200203290 at [13] ; Priest v New South Wales [2006] NSWSC 12; BC200600180 at [126]–[134] . Circumstances that are relevantly different from the ordinary may be characterised as “special” notwithstanding that they are neither “extremely unusual, uncommon or exceptional”: Keating v South East Sydney Illawarra Area Health Service (NSWSC, Hall J, No 20232 of 2005, 7 July 2006, BC200611518) at [24]–[25].

Characterisation of the circumstances as special can be impressionistically influenced by a wide range of factors, including the nature and extent of the evidence apparently likely to be available to the respective parties. Examples in which the “special reasons” criterion has been applied include:
infant parties: Schutt v Queenan [2000] NSWCA 341; BC200007963 at [11]–[14] (infant plaintiff — absence of other available evidence — special reasons);

medical negligence claims: Keating v South East Sydney Illawarra Area Health Service (NSWSC, Hall J, No 20232 of 2005, 7 July 2006, BC200611518) at [28] (complex medical negligence claim — limited information available concerning doctor’s knowledge and diagnostic reasoning — special reasons);

claims related to special employment: Priest v New South Wales [2006] NSWSC 12; BC200600180 at [126]–[134] (damages claim by former police officer suffering psychiatric injury from alleged victimisation as “whistle blower” — difficulty in obtaining direct witness evidence, relevant documents such as internal policies and protocols uniquely in possession of defendant — unusual and exceptional factors satisfy “special reasons” test);
claims related to unusual accident circumstances: Haywood v Collaroy Services Beach Club [2005] NSWSC 1203; BC200510265 (fall over railing — discovery of design and prior accidents — not necessary).
